title: Gastric Outlet Obstruction
diagnosis_topic: Obstruction of the distal stomach due to peptic ulcer or malignancy
setup_script: A 70-year-old man reports persistent vomiting of partially digested food several hours after meals, early satiety and weight loss. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease but has not taken proton pump inhibitors.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/65 mmHg, HR 100 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 36.8 C.
Non-bilious vomiting of undigested food, early satiety, bloating and weight loss of 12 lbs; no hematemesis or melena.
Emaciated appearance, succussion splash in epigastrium and visible peristalsis.
Metabolic alkalosis with hypokalemia and hypochloremia; BUN/Cr elevated due to dehydration.
Aspirates 1 L of foul-smelling gastric contents; relieves pain temporarily.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders upper GI series or CT
dynamic_flow.reply: Shows markedly dilated stomach with narrow passage at pylorus; no mass on imaging.
Ulcerated pyloric channel with edema causing obstruction; biopsies to rule out malignancy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If obstruction secondary to benign ulcer
dynamic_flow.reply: Treat with IV PPI, H. pylori eradication and consider endoscopic balloon dilation; plan for definitive surgery (vagotomy and pyloroplasty) if refractory.
Staging and surgical planning for distal gastrectomy or gastrojejunostomy bypass; palliative stenting for unresectable cases.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays decompression and rehydration
dynamic_flow.reply: Progressive dehydration, electrolyte imbalance and aspiration risk.
Nutritional support, gradual advancement of diet and monitoring for dumping syndrome in surgical patients.
Importance of adhering to PPI therapy, avoiding NSAIDs and following up for repeat endoscopy to confirm healing.

critical_decision_points: Evaluation of gastric outlet obstruction with history, physical and imaging
Resuscitation with nasogastric decompression and correction of electrolyte abnormalities
Endoscopic assessment to differentiate benign ulcer from malignancy
Medical, endoscopic and surgical management options based on etiology
Postoperative nutritional management and prevention of recurrence
